Technical Projects

Neighborhood

July 2020 - August 2020

During the COVID-19 pandemic, I designed a full-stack web application called Neighborhood to allow neighbors to help each other out by posting their needs and offers of help.

As I began noticing shortages of items like flour and yeast, I wanted to help out in my own way during the pandemic.

I was also inspired by informal exchanges of baked goods and packs of Costco mozzarella cheese that I had been having with my friends since quarantine began, as well as my mom's grocery runs for elderly neighbors.

The thought sprung into my mind that I could create an online platform for neighbors to help each other out, so I built Neighborhood.

I used MongoDB and Express for the backend, React for the frontend, Redux for state management, JSON Web Tokens for user authentication, and Reactstrap to integrate Bootstrap components with React, in a Node.js environment. I also used Mongoose.

biggest takeaways: MongoDB, Express, React, Node.js, Redux, JSON Web Tokens, Reactstrap

Rewriting the Code Onboarding Console

May 2020 - August 2020


As part of Rewriting the Code's (RTC) Rewrite Your Summer program, I designed an onboarding console to help new RTC Fellows and members learn professional etiquette.

After analyzing data from a survey of RTC Fellows and members about the current RTC onboarding process, I curated the most essential professional guidelines material provided by RTC into 5 modules and created questions and scenarios for each module to reinforce the information in each.

Using HTML, CSS, Bootstrap, and JavaScript, I designed and built the dashboard and module pages, and integrated gamification (multiple choice quiz questions) into the project to make the onboarding process more engaging.

This onboarding console will be used by the 7000+ women in computer science in the RTC community so that they can learn about RTC professional guidelines when they join RTC, which seeks to promote and uplift women in computer science.

biggest takeaways: HTML, CSS, Bootstrap, JavaScript

News Aggregator

July 2020


In the past few years, fake news has been one of the biggest problems facing our society. And amid the coronavirus crisis, I've become even more concerned about fake news circulating on the web because of false theories about the virus that may cause people to participate in unsafe behavior.

So, combining my passion for tech with an interest in journalism, I built a news aggregator web application using Angular and the News API.

One of my goals for the summer of 2020 was to learn web development frameworks, so I taught myself Angular.

My News Aggregator app is component-based, and I used Angular services to make HTTP requests to the News API, and thus display automatically updated top headlines.

My app also allows users to search for news topics from trusted publications, and research and vet publications.

biggest takeaways: Angular, News API, HTML, CSS, TypeScript

Portfolio Website

December 2019 - Present

This portfolio website!

Using HTML, CSS, Sass, and JavaScript, I built my portfolio website from scratch, so that I could showcase my work. I used Sass, which is then compiled into CSS, for the styling of this website. I used JavaScript to make my website more interactive. The graphic design and layout of this website is also of my own conception.

My website is responsive and can be viewed on devices with screens of any size.

biggest takeaways: HTML, CSS, Sass, JavaScript, Responsive Websites

Astrophysics Research at the Summer Science Program

June 2018 - July 2018

As one of 36 students chosen to attend the 2018 Summer Science Program in Astrophysics in New Mexico, I used Etscorn Observatory's Celestron-14 telescope to observe near-Earth asteroid 2002 UX and calculate its position (in right ascension and declination) throughout the summer. Due to its dimness, 2002 UX was a particularly difficult asteroid to track.

With the data I collected, I used Python to determine the asteroid's orbital elements that uniquely define its orbit through the iterative Method of Gauss. I used differential correction to improve calculations of the orbital elements, and calculated uncertainties with Monte Carlo sampling. I successfully determined and visualized the orbit of 2002 UX.

Additionally, I used Swift integration software to perform orbital integration and run multiple simulations to determine what might happen to 2002 UX after many years. I discovered that 2002 UX had probabilities of colliding with the Earth, Sun, Venus, and Mars.

My team published the data we had collected on the positions of asteroid 2002 UX in the Minor Planet Center Supplement: Lum M., Noel A., & Valadez C. 2018, “New Observations of Near-Earth Asteroid 283729 (2002 UX),” M.P.S. 906049.

We also used LaTeX to write an 18-page orbit determination report.

biggest takeaways: Astrophysics, Telescope Techniques, Python, Orbit Determination (Method of Gauss), differential correction, Monte Carlo sampling, LaTeX

Research at the California State Summer School for Mathematics & Science (COSMOS) UC Davis

July 2017 - August 2017

At COSMOS UC Davis, I was in Cluster 1: Quantum Mechanics and Applications to Nanotechnology.

I learned to program in C and also learned basics in electronics. My time at COSMOS culminated in building a scanning tunneling microscope (STM) to take 3D images of surfaces at the atomic level. The STM uses the quantum effect of tunneling by applying a voltage between the STM's conducting tip and the surface of the sample being studied. This voltage sends electrons to the sample surface. I used C for the software side of the project. My STM successfully took images of samples at microscopic levels and could be used to conduct more research in nanotechnology.

biggest takeaways: C, Electronics, Quantum Mechanics, Nanotechnology

I built this website using HTML, CSS, Sass, and JavaScript.
